EXECUTIVE ADVISORY COMMITTEE — An advisory committee to the President, for
consultation on matters in which consultation of the entire Board is imprac¬
tical or impossible because of time pressure. The President would normally
ask, to serve in this capacity, the chairman of the Board, the chairman of
the Radio Board, the chairman of the Television Board, and possibly another
person if this appears desirable.
GRAMS-IN-A ID COMMITTEE — When funds are available to permit the making of
grants-in-aid for the production of outstanding radio programs, this committee
determines the standards to be established for such grants, arranges for proper
notification to members, carefully considers, and weighs the respective merits
of, proposals for such radio programs, and then makes recommendations as to
which proposals should receive grants, and the sums to be allocated for eac .
INSTRUCTIONAL TELEVISION COMMITTEE — (Formerly the Closed-Circuit TV Committee)
This committee is concerned with television as used for direct instruction and
advises the President and Board on matters in this area, including possible
Association activities (research, seminars, publications, etc.). Its functions
include determination of needs in this area, investigation of new uses of T
for instruction, recruitment of instructional personnel members for the NAEB,
and such other appropriate duties as called upon to perform.
INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS COMMITTEE — * (The role of this committee may be sum¬
marized from a report prepared in 1959 in which the committee listed the
poses of NAEB international activities.) Program imports for use on the NAEB
Radio Network; program exports, to provide outstanding educational programs
from NAEB stations to other nations, liaison with broadcast organizations in
other countries, as reflected in representation at international broadcasting
meetings and similar areas; providing information to other countries through
in-school kits, consultants and seminars; working with the State Department,
USIA-VOA (and such other groups as UNESCO, the UN and others) both in the area
of supplying programs and in working with them for mutual exchange of programs
and other materials with foreign countries, and the promotion of greater under¬
standing in the broadcast and education areas. This committee also large y
handles for the Association, on behalf of the President, numerous relations witn
such organizations as the European Broadcasting Union, International Universi y
of the Air, International Music Council, and foreign broadcast systems, and
advises with appropriate radio network committees on program acceptance and
exchanges.
